Employment Composition Signal

Employment composition signal: tracking shifts across key sectors and categories in the labour market.

As of 2025-11-29

Gemini Summary

The labor market, as indicated by the Employment Composition index, suggests a sentiment of rising slack, despite a recent shift back to a "NEUTRAL" regime. The smoothed Employment Composition (z-score) showed a deterioration, declining to -0.728 in August 2025, which triggered a "COOL (slack rising)" regime. A slight recovery to -0.693 in September 2025 brought it back to "NEUTRAL," but the overall score remains low at 22.86 (on a 0-100 scale). The unemployment rate has steadily increased from 4.1% in October 2024 to 4.4% in September 2025, signaling a loosening labor market. Labor force participation and employment-population ratios remained subdued. (Note: This report is based solely on the provided labor market data and does not cover equities, bonds, precious metals, or industrial metals.)

Technical Summary: Quantitative observations point to a decelerating trend in labor market health through mid-2025, with the smoothed Employment Composition z-score hitting its lowest point in August 2025. While the regime officially moved from "COOL" to "NEUTRAL" in September 2025, the underlying Employment Composition 0-100 score's consistent low value (22.86) suggests persistent weakness rather than a robust recovery. The 3-month momentum for the unemployment rate (unemp_mom_3m) was +0.3 in September 2025, indicating continued upward pressure on joblessness over the short term, implying a cautious technical outlook for labor market tightness.

References:

  • Employment Composition (CPS) metrics (Latest Data: 2025-09-01). Particularly relevant are Employment_Composition_Smoothed, Employment_Regime, and unemployment_rate.
  • Publicly available data that would enhance this analysis includes: equity market indices (e.g., S&P 500), bond yields (e.g., US 10-year Treasury), precious metal prices (e.g., Gold Spot), industrial metal prices (e.g., Copper Futures), inflation rates (CPI/PCE), and wage growth indicators.
